From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: Chauffer

English

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • (UK) IPA(key): /ˈt͡ʃɔː.fə/

Etymology 1

[edit]

Compare French chauffoir, a kind of stove, from chauffer (“to heat”). See chafe.

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • choffer

Noun

[edit]

chauffer (plural chauffers)

  1. A small, portable stove.
  2. A chafing dish.
  3. (chemistry) A table stove or small furnace, usually a cylindrical box of sheet iron, with a grate at the bottom, and an open top.[1]

Etymology 2

[edit]

Noun

[edit]

chauffer

  1. Misspelling of chauffeur.

Verb

[edit]

chauffer

  1. Misspelling of chauffeur.

References

[edit]
  1. ^ “chauffer”, in Webster’s Revised Unabridged Dictionary, Springfield, Mass.: G. & C. Merriam, 1913, →OCLC.

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Middle French chauffer, from Old French chauffer, chaufer, from Vulgar Latin *cal(e)fāre, from Latin calfacere or calefacere. Compare Occitan caufar, calfar, Catalan calfar.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ʃo.fe/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (Canada (Shawinigan)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

chauffer

  1. to heat, to warm, to warm up
  2. (slang) to tease, to entice sexually, to arouse
    Synonyms: allumer, aguicher
  3. (Quebec) to drive (a vehicle)

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Derived terms

[edit]
  • chauffage
  • chauffe-eau
  • chauffer à blanc
  • chaufferette
  • chaufferie
  • chauffeur
  • chauffoir
  • de quel bois quelqu'un se chauffe
  • réchauffer

Further reading

[edit]
  • “chauffer”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

Old French

[edit]

Verb

[edit]

chauffer

  1. alternative form of chaufer

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb conjugates as a first-group verb ending in -er. The forms that would normally end in *-ff, *-ffs, *-fft are modified to f, s, t. Old French conjugation varies significantly by date and by region. The following conjugation should be treated as a guide.

    Conjugation of chauffer (see also Appendix:Old French verbs)
simple compound
infinitive chauffer avoir chauffé
gerund en chauffant gerund of avoir + past participle
present participle chauffant
past participle chauffé
person singular plural
first second third first second third
indicative jo tu il nos vos il

tenses 		present chauf chauffes chauffe chauffons chauffez chauffent
imperfect chauffoie, chauffeie, chauffoe, chauffeve chauffoies, chauffeies, chauffoes, chauffeves chauffoit, chauffeit, chauffot, chauffeve chauffiiens, chauffiens chauffiiez, chauffiez chauffoient, chauffeient, chauffoent, chauffevent
preterite chauffai chauffas chauffa chauffames chauffastes chaufferent
future chaufferai chaufferas chauffera chaufferons chaufferoiz, chauffereiz, chaufferez chaufferont
conditional chaufferoie, chauffereie chaufferoies, chauffereies chaufferoit, chauffereit chaufferiiens, chaufferiens chaufferiiez, chaufferiez chaufferoient, chauffereient
